calidhayte.calibrate

Contains code used to perform a range of univariate and multivariate regressions on provided data.

Acts as a wrapper for scikit-learn 1, XGBoost 2 and PyMC (via Bambi) 3

  1. https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/classes.html ↩

  2. https://xgboost.readthedocs.io/en/stable/python/python_api.html ↩

  3. https://bambinos.github.io/bambi/api/ ↩

   1""" Contains code used to perform a range of univariate and multivariate
   2regressions on provided data.
   3
   4Acts as a wrapper for scikit-learn [^skl], XGBoost [^xgb] and PyMC (via Bambi)
   5[^pmc]
   6
   7[^skl]: https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/classes.html
   8[^xgb]: https://xgboost.readthedocs.io/en/stable/python/python_api.html
   9[^pmc]: https://bambinos.github.io/bambi/api/
  10"""

  43def cont_strat_folds(
  44    df: pd.DataFrame,
  45    target_var: str,
  46    splits: int = 5,
  47    strat_groups: int = 5,
  48    validation_size: float = 0.1,
  49    seed: int = 62,
  50) -> pd.DataFrame:
  51    """
  52    Creates stratified k-folds on continuous variable
  53
  54    Parameters
  55    ----------
  56    df : pd.DataFrame
  57        Target data to stratify on.
  58    target_var : str
  59        Target feature name.
  60    splits : int, default=5
  61        Number of folds to make.
  62    strat_groups : int, default=10
  63        Number of groups to split data in to for stratification.
  64    validation_size : float, default = 0.1
  65        Size of measurements to keep aside for validation
  66    seed : int, default=62
  67        Random state to use.
  68
  69    Returns
  70    -------
  71    pd.DataFrame
  72        `y_df` with added 'Fold' column, specifying which test data fold
  73        variable corresponds to.
  74
  75    Examples
  76    --------
  77    >>> df = pd.read_csv('data.csv')
  78    >>> df
  79    |    | x | a | b |
  80    |    |   |   |   |
  81    |  0 |2.3|1.8|7.2|
  82    |  1 |3.2|9.6|4.5|
  83    |....|...|...|...|
  84    |1000|2.3|4.5|2.2|
  85    >>> df_with_folds = const_strat_folds(
  86            df=df,
  87            target='a',
  88            splits=3,
  89            strat_groups=3.
  90            seed=78
  91        )
  92    >>> df_with_folds
  93    |    | x | a | b |Fold|
  94    |    |   |   |   |    |
  95    |  0 |2.3|1.8|7.2| 2  |
  96    |  1 |3.2|9.6|4.5| 1  |
  97    |....|...|...|...|....|
  98    |1000|2.3|4.5|2.2| 0  |
  99
 100    All folds should have a roughly equal distribution of values for 'a'
 101
 102    """
 103    _df = df.copy()
 104    _df["Fold"] = "Validation"
 105    skf = StratifiedKFold(n_splits=splits, random_state=seed, shuffle=True)
 106    _df["Group"] = pd.qcut(_df.loc[:, target_var], strat_groups, labels=False)
 107
 108    group_label = _df.loc[:, "Group"]
 109
 110    train_set, val_set = train_test_split(
 111        _df,
 112        test_size=validation_size,
 113        random_state=seed,
 114        shuffle=True,
 115        stratify=group_label,
 116    )
 117
 118    group_label = train_set.loc[:, "Group"]
 119
 120    for fold_number, (_, v) in enumerate(skf.split(group_label, group_label)):
 121        _temp_df = train_set.iloc[v, :]
 122        _temp_df.loc[:, "Fold"] = fold_number
 123        train_set.iloc[v, :] = _temp_df
 124    return pd.concat([train_set, val_set]).sort_index().drop("Group", axis=1)
 125
 126
 127class Calibrate:
 128    """
 129    Calibrate x against y using a range of different methods provided by
 130    scikit-learn[^skl], xgboost[^xgb] and PyMC (via Bambi)[^pmc].
 131
 132    [^skl]: https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/classes.html
 133    [^xgb]: https://xgboost.readthedocs.io/en/stable/python/python_api.html
 134    [^pmc]: https://bambinos.github.io/bambi/api/
 135
 136    Examples
 137    --------
 138    >>> from calidhayte.calibrate import Calibrate
 139    >>> import pandas as pd
 140    >>>
 141    >>> x = pd.read_csv('independent.csv')
 142    >>> x
 143    |   | a | b |
 144    | 0 |2.3|3.2|
 145    | 1 |3.4|3.1|
 146    |...|...|...|
 147    |100|3.7|2.1|
 148    >>>
 149    >>> y = pd.read_csv('dependent.csv')
 150    >>> y
 151    |   | a |
 152    | 0 |7.8|
 153    | 1 |9.9|
 154    |...|...|
 155    |100|9.5|
 156    >>>
 157    >>> calibration = Calibrate(
 158        x_data=x,
 159        y_data=y,
 160        target='a',
 161        folds=5,
 162        strat_groups=5,
 163        scaler = [
 164            'Standard Scale',
 165            'MinMax Scale'
 166            ],
 167        seed=62
 168    )
 169    >>> calibration.linreg()
 170    >>> calibration.lars()
 171    >>> calibration.omp()
 172    >>> calibration.ransac()
 173    >>> calibration.random_forest()
 174    >>>
 175    >>> models = calibration.return_models()
 176    >>> list(models.keys())
 177    [
 178        'Linear Regression',
 179        'Least Angle Regression',
 180        'Orthogonal Matching Pursuit',
 181        'RANSAC',
 182        'Random Forest'
 183    ]
 184    >>> list(models['Linear Regression'].keys())
 185    ['Standard Scale', 'MinMax Scale']
 186    >>> list(models['Linear Regression']['Standard Scale'].keys())
 187    ['a', 'a + b']
 188    >>> list(models['Linear Regression']['Standard Scale']['a'].keys())
 189    [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]
 190    >>> type(models['Linear Regression']['Standard Scale']['a'][0])
 191    <class sklearn.pipeline.Pipeline>
 192    >>> pipeline = models['Linear Regression']['Standard Scale']['a'][0]
 193    >>> x_new = pd.read_csv('independent_new.csv')
 194    >>> x_new
 195    |   | a | b |
 196    | 0 |3.5|2.7|
 197    | 1 |4.0|1.1|
 198    |...|...|...|
 199    |100|2.3|2.1|
 200    >>> pipeline.transform(x_new)
 201    |   | a |
 202    | 0 |9.7|
 203    | 1 |9.1|
 204    |...|...|
 205    |100|6.7|
 206
 207    """
 208
 209    def __init__(
 210        self,
 211        x_data: pd.DataFrame,
 212        y_data: pd.DataFrame,
 213        target: str,
 214        all_sec_vals: bool = False,
 215        folds: int = 5,
 216        strat_groups: int = 10,
 217        scaler: Union[
 218            Iterable[
 219                Literal[
 220                    "None",
 221                    "Standard Scale",
 222                    "MinMax Scale",
 223                    "Yeo-Johnson Transform",
 224                    "Box-Cox Transform",
 225                    "Quantile Transform (Uniform)",
 226                    "Quantile Transform (Gaussian)",
 227                ]
 228            ],
 229            Literal[
 230                "All",
 231                "None",
 232                "Standard Scale",
 233                "MinMax Scale",
 234                "Yeo-Johnson Transform",
 235                "Box-Cox Transform",
 236                "Quantile Transform (Uniform)",
 237                "Quantile Transform (Gaussian)",
 238            ],
 239        ] = "None",
 240        random_search_iterations: int = 25,
 241        validation_size: float = 0.1,
 242        verbosity: int = 0,
 243        n_jobs: int = -1,
 244        pickle_path: Optional[Path] = None,
 245        seed: int = 62,
 246    ):
 247        """Initialises class
 248
 249        Used to compare one set of measurements against another.
 250        It can perform both univariate and multivariate regression, though
 251        some techniques can only do one or the other. Multivariate regression
 252        can only be performed when secondary variables are provided.
 253
 254        Parameters
 255        ----------
 256        x_data : pd.DataFrame
 257            Data to be calibrated.
 258        y_data : pd.DataFrame
 259            'True' data to calibrate against.
 260        target : str
 261            Column name of the primary feature to use in calibration, must be
 262            the name of a column in both `x_data` and `y_data`.
 263        all_sec_vals : bool, default=False
 264            Iterate over all secondary variable combinations or just all/none
 265        folds : int, default=5
 266            Number of folds to split the data into, using stratified k-fold.
 267        strat_groups : int, default=10
 268            Number of groups to stratify against, the data will be split into
 269            n equally sized bins where n is the value of `strat_groups`.
 270        scaler : iterable of {<br>\
 271            'None',<br>\
 272            'Standard Scale',<br>\
 273            'MinMax Scale',<br>\
 274            'Yeo-Johnson Transform',<br>\
 275            'Box-Cox Transform',<br>\
 276            'Quantile Transform (Uniform)',<br>\
 277            'Quantile Transform (Gaussian)',<br>\
 278            } or {<br>\
 279            'All',<br>\
 280            'None',<br>\
 281            'Standard Scale',<br>\
 282            'MinMax Scale',<br>\
 283            'Yeo-Johnson Transform',<br>\
 284            'Box-Cox Transform',<br>\
 285            'Quantile Transform (Uniform)',<br>\
 286            'Quantile Transform (Gaussian)',<br>\
 287            }, default='None'
 288            The scaling/transform method (or list of methods) to apply to the
 289            data
 290        seed : int, default=62
 291            Random state to use when shuffling and splitting the data into n
 292            folds. Ensures repeatability.
 293
 294        Raises
 295        ------
 296        ValueError
 297            Raised if the target variables (e.g. 'NO2') is not a column name in
 298            both dataframes.
 299            Raised if `scaler` is not str, tuple or list
 300        """
 301        if target not in x_data.columns or target not in y_data.columns:
 302            raise ValueError(f"{target} does not exist in both columns.")
 303        join_index = (
 304            x_data.join(y_data, how="inner", lsuffix="x", rsuffix="y")
 305            .dropna()
 306            .index
 307        )
 308        """
 309        The common indices between `x_data` and `y_data`, excluding missing
 310        values
 311        """
 312        self.x_data: pd.DataFrame = x_data.loc[join_index, :]
 313        """
 314        The data to be calibrated.
 315        """
 316        self.target: str = target
 317        """
 318        The name of the column in both `x_data` and `y_data` that
 319        will be used as the x and y variables in the calibration.
 320        """
 321        self.scaler_list: dict[str, Any] = {
 322            "None": None,
 323            "Standard Scale": pre.StandardScaler(),
 324            "MinMax Scale": pre.MinMaxScaler(),
 325            "Yeo-Johnson Transform": pre.PowerTransformer(
 326                method="yeo-johnson"
 327            ),
 328            "Box-Cox Transform": pre.PowerTransformer(method="box-cox"),
 329            "Quantile Transform (Uniform)": pre.QuantileTransformer(
 330                output_distribution="uniform"
 331            ),
 332            "Quantile Transform (Gaussian)": pre.QuantileTransformer(
 333                output_distribution="normal"
 334            ),
 335        }
 336        """
 337        Keys for scaling algorithms available in the pipelines
 338        """
 339        self.scaler: list[str] = list()
 340        """
 341        The scaling algorithm(s) to preprocess the data with
 342        """
 343        self.y_data = cont_strat_folds(
 344            y_data.loc[join_index, :],
 345            target,
 346            folds,
 347            strat_groups,
 348            validation_size,
 349            seed,
 350        )
 351        """
 352        The data that `x_data` will be calibrated against. A '*Fold*'
 353        column is added using the `const_strat_folds` function which splits
 354        the data into k stratified folds (where k is the value of
 355        `folds`). It splits the continuous measurements into n bins (where n
 356        is the value of `strat_groups`) and distributes each bin equally
 357        across all folds. This significantly reduces the chances of one fold
 358        containing a skewed distribution relative to the whole dataset.
 359        """
 360        if isinstance(scaler, str):
 361            if scaler == "All":
 362                if bool(self.x_data.le(0).any(axis=None)) or bool(
 363                    self.y_data.drop("Fold", axis=1).le(0).any(axis=None)
 364                ):
 365                    self.scaler_list.pop("Box-Cox Transform")
 366                    warnings.warn(
 367                        "WARN: "
 368                        "Box-Cox is not compatible with provided measurements"
 369                    )
 370                self.scaler.extend(self.scaler_list.keys())
 371            elif scaler in self.scaler_list.keys():
 372                self.scaler.append(scaler)
 373            else:
 374                self.scaler.append("None")
 375                warnings.warn(f"Scaling algorithm {scaler} not recognised")
 376        elif isinstance(scaler, (tuple, list)):
 377            for sc in scaler:
 378                if sc == "Box-Cox Transform" and not any(
 379                    (
 380                        bool(self.x_data.lt(0).any(axis=None)),
 381                        bool(self.y_data.lt(0).any(axis=None)),
 382                    )
 383                ):
 384                    warnings.warn(
 385                        "Box-Cox is not compatible with provided measurements"
 386                    )
 387                    continue
 388                if sc in self.scaler_list.keys():
 389                    self.scaler.append(sc)
 390                else:
 391                    warnings.warn(f"Scaling algorithm {sc} not recognised")
 392        else:
 393            raise ValueError(
 394                "scaler parameter should be string, list or tuple"
 395            )
 396        if not self.scaler:
 397            warnings.warn(
 398                "No valid scaling algorithms provided, defaulting to None"
 399            )
 400            self.scaler.append("None")
 401
 402        self.models: dict[
 403            str,  # Technique name
 404            dict[
 405                str,  # Scaling technique
 406                dict[str, dict[int, Pipeline]],  # Variable combo  # Fold
 407            ],
 408        ] = dict()
 409        """
 410        The calibrated models. They are stored in a nested structure as
 411        follows:
 412        1. Primary Key, name of the technique (e.g Lasso Regression).
 413        2. Scaling technique (e.g Yeo-Johnson Transform).
 414        3. Combination of variables used or `target` if calibration is
 415        univariate (e.g "`target` + a + b).
 416        4. Fold, which fold was used excluded from the calibration. If data
 417        if 5-fold cross validated, a key of 4 indicates the data was trained on
 418        folds 0-3.
 419
 420        ```mermaid
 421            stateDiagram-v2
 422              models --> Technique
 423              state Technique {
 424                [*] --> Scaling
 425                [*]: The calibration technique used
 426                [*]: (e.g "Lasso Regression")
 427                state Scaling {
 428                  [*] --> Variables
 429                  [*]: The scaling technique used
 430                  [*]: (e.g "Yeo-Johnson Transform")
 431                  state Variables {
 432                    [*] : The combination of variables used
 433                    [*] : (e.g "x + a + b")
 434                    [*] --> Fold
 435                    state Fold {
 436                     [*] : Which fold was excluded from training data
 437                     [*] : (e.g 4 indicates folds 0-3 were used to train)
 438                    }
 439                  }
 440                }
 441              }
 442        ```
 443
 444        """
 445        self.folds: int = folds
 446        """
 447        The number of folds used in k-fold cross validation
 448        """
 449        self.rs_iter: int = random_search_iterations
 450        """
 451        Number of iterations to use in random search
 452        """
 453        self.verbosity: int = verbosity
 454        """
 455        Verbosity of output when using random search
 456        """
 457        self.n_jobs: int = n_jobs
 458        """
 459        Number of processor cores to use
 460        """
 461        self.pkl = pickle_path
 462        """
 463        Path to save pickle files to, or None if pipelines are stored in memory
 464        """
 465        self.all_sec_vals = all_sec_vals
 466        """
 467        Whether to test all combinations of secondary variables or just
 468        all/none
 469        """
 470
 471    def _sklearn_regression_meta(
 472        self,
 473        reg: Union[
 474            skl.base.RegressorMixin,
 475            RandomizedSearchCV,
 476            GAM,
 477            Literal["t", "gaussian"],
 478        ],
 479        name: str,
 480        min_coeffs: int = 1,
 481        max_coeffs: int = (sys.maxsize * 2) + 1,
 482        random_search: bool = False,
 483    ):
 484        """
 485        Metaclass, formats data and uses sklearn classifier to
 486        fit x to y
 487
 488        Parameters
 489        ----------
 490        reg : sklearn.base.RegressorMixin or str
 491            Classifier to use, or distribution family to use for bayesian.
 492        name : str
 493            Name of classification technique to save pipeline to.
 494        min_coeffs : int, default=1
 495            Minimum number of coefficients for technique.
 496        max_coeffs : int, default=(sys.maxsize * 2) + 1
 497            Maximum number of coefficients for technique.
 498        random_search : bool
 499            Whether RandomizedSearch is used or not
 500
 501        Raises
 502        ------
 503        NotImplementedError
 504            PyMC currently doesn't work, TODO
 505        """
 506        x_secondary_cols = self.x_data.drop(self.target, axis=1).columns
 507        # All columns in x_data that aren't the target variable
 508        if len(x_secondary_cols) > 0:
 509            if self.all_sec_vals:
 510                products = [[np.nan, col] for col in x_secondary_cols]
 511                secondary_vals = pd.MultiIndex.from_product(products)
 512            else:
 513                secondary_vals = [None, list(x_secondary_cols)]
 514        else:
 515            secondary_vals = [None]
 516        # Get all possible combinations of secondary variables in a pandas
 517        # MultiIndex
 518        if self.models.get(name) is None:
 519            self.models[name] = dict()
 520            # If the classification technique hasn't been used yet,
 521            # add its key to the models dictionary
 522        for scaler in self.scaler:
 523            if self.models[name].get(scaler) is None:
 524                self.models[name][scaler] = dict()
 525                # If the scaling technique hasn't been used with the
 526                # classification
 527                # technique yet, add its key to the nested dictionary
 528            for sec_vals in secondary_vals:
 529                # Loop over all combinations of secondary values
 530                if sec_vals is not None:
 531                    vals = [self.target] + [v for v in sec_vals if v == v]
 532                else:
 533                    vals = [self.target]
 534                vals_str = " + ".join(vals)
 535                if len(vals) < min_coeffs or len(vals) > max_coeffs:
 536                    # Skip if number of coeffs doesn't lie within acceptable
 537                    # range
 538                    # for technique. For example, isotonic regression
 539                    # only works with one variable
 540                    continue
 541                self.models[name][scaler][vals_str] = dict()
 542                #                if random_search:
 543                #                    pipeline = Pipeline([
 544                #                        ("Selector", ColumnTransformer([
 545                #                       ("selector", "passthrough", vals)
 546                #                            ], remainder="drop")
 547                #                         ),
 548                #                        ("Scaler", self.scaler_list[scaler]),
 549                #                        ("Regression", reg)
 550                #                        ])
 551                #                    pipeline.fit(
 552                #                        self.x_data,
 553                #                        self.y_data.loc[:, self.target]
 554                #                            )
 555                #   self.models[name][scaler][vals_str][0] = dc(pipeline)
 556                #                    continue
 557                #
 558                for fold in self.y_data.loc[:, "Fold"].unique():
 559                    if fold == "Validation":
 560                        continue
 561                    y_data = self.y_data[
 562                        ~self.y_data.loc[:, "Fold"].isin([fold, "Validation"])
 563                    ]
 564                    if reg in ["t", "gaussian"]:
 565                        # If using PyMC bayesian model,
 566                        # then store result in pipeline
 567                        # Currently doesn't work as PyMC models
 568                        # can't be pickled, so don't function with deepcopy.
 569                        # Needs looking into
 570                        raise NotImplementedError(
 571                            "PyMC functions currently don't work with deepcopy"
 572                        )
 573                    #                    sc = scalers[scaler]
 574                    #                    if sc is not None:
 575                    #                        x_data = sc.fit_transform(
 576                    #                   self.x_data.loc[y_data.index, :]
 577                    #                                )
 578                    #                    else:
 579                    #           x_data = self.x_data.loc[y_data.index, :]
 580                    #               x_data['y'] = y_data.loc[:, self.target]
 581                    #                    model = bmb.Model(
 582                    #                            f"y ~ {vals_str}",
 583                    #                            x_data,
 584                    #                            family=reg
 585                    #                            )
 586                    #                    _ = model.fit(
 587                    #                        progressbar=False,
 588                    #                        **kwargs
 589                    #                        )
 590                    #                    pipeline = Pipeline([
 591                    #                        ("Scaler", scaler),
 592                    #                        ("Regression", model)
 593                    #                        ])
 594                    else:
 595                        # If using scikit-learn API compatible classifier,
 596                        # Build pipeline and fit to
 597                        pipeline = Pipeline(
 598                            [
 599                                (
 600                                    "Selector",
 601                                    ColumnTransformer(
 602                                        [("selector", "passthrough", vals)],
 603                                        remainder="drop",
 604                                    ),
 605                                ),
 606                                ("Scaler", self.scaler_list[scaler]),
 607                                ("Regression", reg),
 608                            ]
 609                        )
 610                        pipeline.fit(
 611                            self.x_data.loc[y_data.index, :],
 612                            y_data.loc[:, self.target],
 613                        )
 614                    if isinstance(self.pkl, Path):
 615                        pkl_path = self.pkl / name / scaler / vals_str
 616                        pkl_path.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
 617                        pkl_file = pkl_path / f"{fold}.pkl"
 618                        with pkl_file.open("wb") as pkl:
 619                            pickle.dump(pipeline, pkl)
 620                        self.models[name][scaler][vals_str][fold] = pkl_file
 621                    else:
 622                        self.models[name][scaler][vals_str][fold] = dc(
 623                            pipeline
 624                        )
 625
 626    def pymc_bayesian(
 627        self,
 628        family: Literal[
 629            "Gaussian",
 630            "Student T",
 631        ] = "Gaussian",
 632        name: str = " PyMC Bayesian",
 633        **kwargs,
 634    ):
 635        """
 636        Performs bayesian linear regression (either uni or multivariate)
 637        fitting x on y.
 638
 639        Performs bayesian linear regression, both univariate and multivariate,
 640        on X against y. More details can be found at:
 641        https://pymc.io/projects/examples/en/latest/generalized_linear_models/
 642        GLM-robust.html
 643
 644        Parameters
 645        ----------
 646        family : {'Gaussian', 'Student T'}, default='Gaussian'
 647            Statistical distribution to fit measurements to. Options are:
 648                - Gaussian
 649                - Student T
 650        """
 651        # Define model families
 652        model_families: dict[str, Literal["t", "gaussian"]] = {
 653            "Gaussian": "gaussian",
 654            "Student T": "t",
 655        }
 656        self._sklearn_regression_meta(
 657            model_families[family], f"{name} ({model_families})", **kwargs
 658        )
 659

2074                kern.RBF,
2075                kern.Matern,
2076                kern.DotProduct,
2077                kern.WhiteKernel,
2078                kern.CompoundKernel,
2079                kern.ExpSineSquared,
2080            ],
2081            "alpha": uniform(loc=0, scale=1e-8),
2082            "normalize_y": [True, False],
2083        },
2084        **kwargs,
2085    ):
2086        """
2087        Fit x on y via gaussian process regression
2088
2089        Parameters
2090        ----------
2091        name : str, default="Gaussian Process Regression"
2092            Name of classification technique.
2093        random_search : bool, default=False
2094            Whether to perform RandomizedSearch to optimise parameters
2095        parameters : dict[\
2096                str,\
2097                Union[\
2098                    scipy.stats.rv_continuous,\
2099                    List[Union[int, str, float]]\
2100                ]\
2101            ], default=Preset distributions
2102            The parameters used in RandomizedSearchCV
2103        """
2104        if random_search:
2105            classifier = RandomizedSearchCV(
2106                gp.GaussianProcessRegressor(**kwargs),
2107                parameters,
2108                n_iter=self.rs_iter,
2109                verbose=self.verbosity,
2110                n_jobs=self.n_jobs,
2111                cv=self.folds,
2112            )
2113        else:
2114            classifier = gp.GaussianProcessRegressor(**kwargs)
2115        self._sklearn_regression_meta(
2116            classifier,
2117            f'{name}{" (Random Search)" if random_search else ""}',
2118            random_search=random_search,
2119        )

2367        """
2368        Returns the measurements used, with missing values and

2370

2375

2384    def return_models(
2385        self,
2386    ) -> dict[
2387        str,  # Technique
2388        dict[
2389            str,  # Scaling method
2390            dict[str, dict[int, Pipeline]],  # Variables used  # Fold
2391        ],
2392    ]:
2393        """
2394        Returns the models stored in the object
2395
2396        Returns
2397        -------
2398        dict[str, str, str, int, Pipeline]
2399            The calibrated models. They are stored in a nested structure as
2400            follows:
2401            1. Primary Key, name of the technique (e.g Lasso Regression).
2402            2. Scaling technique (e.g Yeo-Johnson Transform).
2403            3. Combination of variables used or `target` if calibration is
2404            univariate (e.g "`target` + a + b).
2405            4. Fold, which fold was used excluded from the calibration. If data
2406            folds 0-3.
2407            if 5-fold cross validated, a key of 4 indicates the data was
2408            trained on
2409        """
2410        return self.models
2411
2412    def clear_models(self):
2413        """ """
2414        del self.models
2415        self.models = dict()
def cont_strat_folds( df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, target_var: str, splits: int = 5, strat_groups: int = 5, validation_size: float = 0.1, seed: int = 62) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
 44def cont_strat_folds(
 45    df: pd.DataFrame,
 46    target_var: str,
 47    splits: int = 5,
 48    strat_groups: int = 5,
 49    validation_size: float = 0.1,
 50    seed: int = 62,
 51) -> pd.DataFrame:
 52    """
 53    Creates stratified k-folds on continuous variable
 54
 55    Parameters
 56    ----------
 57    df : pd.DataFrame
 58        Target data to stratify on.
 59    target_var : str
 60        Target feature name.
 61    splits : int, default=5
 62        Number of folds to make.
 63    strat_groups : int, default=10
 64        Number of groups to split data in to for stratification.
 65    validation_size : float, default = 0.1
 66        Size of measurements to keep aside for validation
 67    seed : int, default=62
 68        Random state to use.
 69
 70    Returns
 71    -------
 72    pd.DataFrame
 73        `y_df` with added 'Fold' column, specifying which test data fold
 74        variable corresponds to.
 75
 76    Examples
 77    --------
 78    >>> df = pd.read_csv('data.csv')
 79    >>> df
 80    |    | x | a | b |
 81    |    |   |   |   |
 82    |  0 |2.3|1.8|7.2|
 83    |  1 |3.2|9.6|4.5|
 84    |....|...|...|...|
 85    |1000|2.3|4.5|2.2|
 86    >>> df_with_folds = const_strat_folds(
 87            df=df,
 88            target='a',
 89            splits=3,
 90            strat_groups=3.
 91            seed=78
 92        )
 93    >>> df_with_folds
 94    |    | x | a | b |Fold|
 95    |    |   |   |   |    |
 96    |  0 |2.3|1.8|7.2| 2  |
 97    |  1 |3.2|9.6|4.5| 1  |
 98    |....|...|...|...|....|
 99    |1000|2.3|4.5|2.2| 0  |
100
101    All folds should have a roughly equal distribution of values for 'a'
102
103    """
104    _df = df.copy()
105    _df["Fold"] = "Validation"
106    skf = StratifiedKFold(n_splits=splits, random_state=seed, shuffle=True)
107    _df["Group"] = pd.qcut(_df.loc[:, target_var], strat_groups, labels=False)
108
109    group_label = _df.loc[:, "Group"]
110
111    train_set, val_set = train_test_split(
112        _df,
113        test_size=validation_size,
114        random_state=seed,
115        shuffle=True,
116        stratify=group_label,
117    )
118
119    group_label = train_set.loc[:, "Group"]
120
121    for fold_number, (_, v) in enumerate(skf.split(group_label, group_label)):
122        _temp_df = train_set.iloc[v, :]
123        _temp_df.loc[:, "Fold"] = fold_number
124        train_set.iloc[v, :] = _temp_df
125    return pd.concat([train_set, val_set]).sort_index().drop("Group", axis=1)

Creates stratified k-folds on continuous variable

Parameters
  • df (pd.DataFrame): Target data to stratify on.
  • target_var (str): Target feature name.
  • splits (int, default=5): Number of folds to make.
  • strat_groups (int, default=10): Number of groups to split data in to for stratification.
  • validation_size (float, default = 0.1): Size of measurements to keep aside for validation
  • seed (int, default=62): Random state to use.
Returns
  • pd.DataFrame: y_df with added 'Fold' column, specifying which test data fold variable corresponds to.
Examples
>>> df = pd.read_csv('data.csv')
>>> df
|    | x | a | b |
|    |   |   |   |
|  0 |2.3|1.8|7.2|
|  1 |3.2|9.6|4.5|
|....|...|...|...|
|1000|2.3|4.5|2.2|
>>> df_with_folds = const_strat_folds(
        df=df,
        target='a',
        splits=3,
        strat_groups=3.
        seed=78
    )
>>> df_with_folds
|    | x | a | b |Fold|
|    |   |   |   |    |
|  0 |2.3|1.8|7.2| 2  |
|  1 |3.2|9.6|4.5| 1  |
|....|...|...|...|....|
|1000|2.3|4.5|2.2| 0  |

All folds should have a roughly equal distribution of values for 'a'

class Calibrate: 
 128class Calibrate:
 129    """
 130    Calibrate x against y using a range of different methods provided by
 131    scikit-learn[^skl], xgboost[^xgb] and PyMC (via Bambi)[^pmc].
 132
 133    [^skl]: https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/classes.html
 134    [^xgb]: https://xgboost.readthedocs.io/en/stable/python/python_api.html
 135    [^pmc]: https://bambinos.github.io/bambi/api/
 136
 137    Examples
 138    --------
 139    >>> from calidhayte.calibrate import Calibrate
 140    >>> import pandas as pd
 141    >>>
 142    >>> x = pd.read_csv('independent.csv')
 143    >>> x
 144    |   | a | b |
 145    | 0 |2.3|3.2|
 146    | 1 |3.4|3.1|
 147    |...|...|...|
 148    |100|3.7|2.1|
 149    >>>
 150    >>> y = pd.read_csv('dependent.csv')
 151    >>> y
 152    |   | a |
 153    | 0 |7.8|
 154    | 1 |9.9|
 155    |...|...|
 156    |100|9.5|
 157    >>>
 158    >>> calibration = Calibrate(
 159        x_data=x,
 160        y_data=y,
 161        target='a',
 162        folds=5,
 163        strat_groups=5,
 164        scaler = [
 165            'Standard Scale',
 166            'MinMax Scale'
 167            ],
 168        seed=62
 169    )
 170    >>> calibration.linreg()
 171    >>> calibration.lars()
 172    >>> calibration.omp()
 173    >>> calibration.ransac()
 174    >>> calibration.random_forest()
 175    >>>
 176    >>> models = calibration.return_models()
 177    >>> list(models.keys())
 178    [
 179        'Linear Regression',
 180        'Least Angle Regression',
 181        'Orthogonal Matching Pursuit',
 182        'RANSAC',
 183        'Random Forest'
 184    ]
 185    >>> list(models['Linear Regression'].keys())
 186    ['Standard Scale', 'MinMax Scale']
 187    >>> list(models['Linear Regression']['Standard Scale'].keys())
 188    ['a', 'a + b']
 189    >>> list(models['Linear Regression']['Standard Scale']['a'].keys())
 190    [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]
 191    >>> type(models['Linear Regression']['Standard Scale']['a'][0])
 192    <class sklearn.pipeline.Pipeline>
 193    >>> pipeline = models['Linear Regression']['Standard Scale']['a'][0]
 194    >>> x_new = pd.read_csv('independent_new.csv')
 195    >>> x_new
 196    |   | a | b |
 197    | 0 |3.5|2.7|
 198    | 1 |4.0|1.1|
 199    |...|...|...|
 200    |100|2.3|2.1|
 201    >>> pipeline.transform(x_new)
 202    |   | a |
 203    | 0 |9.7|
 204    | 1 |9.1|
 205    |...|...|
 206    |100|6.7|
 207
 208    """
 209
 210    def __init__(
 211        self,
 212        x_data: pd.DataFrame,
 213        y_data: pd.DataFrame,
 214        target: str,
 215        all_sec_vals: bool = False,
 216        folds: int = 5,
 217        strat_groups: int = 10,
 218        scaler: Union[
 219            Iterable[
 220                Literal[
 221                    "None",
 222                    "Standard Scale",
 223                    "MinMax Scale",
 224                    "Yeo-Johnson Transform",
 225                    "Box-Cox Transform",
 226                    "Quantile Transform (Uniform)",
 227                    "Quantile Transform (Gaussian)",
 228                ]
 229            ],
 230            Literal[
 231                "All",
 232                "None",
 233                "Standard Scale",
 234                "MinMax Scale",
 235                "Yeo-Johnson Transform",
 236                "Box-Cox Transform",
 237                "Quantile Transform (Uniform)",
 238                "Quantile Transform (Gaussian)",
 239            ],
 240        ] = "None",
 241        random_search_iterations: int = 25,
 242        validation_size: float = 0.1,
 243        verbosity: int = 0,
 244        n_jobs: int = -1,
 245        pickle_path: Optional[Path] = None,
 246        seed: int = 62,
 247    ):
 248        """Initialises class
 249
 250        Used to compare one set of measurements against another.
 251        It can perform both univariate and multivariate regression, though
 252        some techniques can only do one or the other. Multivariate regression
 253        can only be performed when secondary variables are provided.
 254
 255        Parameters
 256        ----------
 257        x_data : pd.DataFrame
 258            Data to be calibrated.
 259        y_data : pd.DataFrame
 260            'True' data to calibrate against.
 261        target : str
 262            Column name of the primary feature to use in calibration, must be
 263            the name of a column in both `x_data` and `y_data`.
 264        all_sec_vals : bool, default=False
 265            Iterate over all secondary variable combinations or just all/none
 266        folds : int, default=5
 267            Number of folds to split the data into, using stratified k-fold.
 268        strat_groups : int, default=10
 269            Number of groups to stratify against, the data will be split into
 270            n equally sized bins where n is the value of `strat_groups`.
 271        scaler : iterable of {<br>\
 272            'None',<br>\
 273            'Standard Scale',<br>\
 274            'MinMax Scale',<br>\
 275            'Yeo-Johnson Transform',<br>\
 276            'Box-Cox Transform',<br>\
 277            'Quantile Transform (Uniform)',<br>\
 278            'Quantile Transform (Gaussian)',<br>\
 279            } or {<br>\
 280            'All',<br>\
 281            'None',<br>\
 282            'Standard Scale',<br>\
 283            'MinMax Scale',<br>\
 284            'Yeo-Johnson Transform',<br>\
 285            'Box-Cox Transform',<br>\
 286            'Quantile Transform (Uniform)',<br>\
 287            'Quantile Transform (Gaussian)',<br>\
 288            }, default='None'
 289            The scaling/transform method (or list of methods) to apply to the
 290            data
 291        seed : int, default=62
 292            Random state to use when shuffling and splitting the data into n
 293            folds. Ensures repeatability.
 294
 295        Raises
 296        ------
 297        ValueError
 298            Raised if the target variables (e.g. 'NO2') is not a column name in
 299            both dataframes.
 300            Raised if `scaler` is not str, tuple or list
 301        """
 302        if target not in x_data.columns or target not in y_data.columns:
 303            raise ValueError(f"{target} does not exist in both columns.")
 304        join_index = (
 305            x_data.join(y_data, how="inner", lsuffix="x", rsuffix="y")
 306            .dropna()
 307            .index
 308        )
 309        """
 310        The common indices between `x_data` and `y_data`, excluding missing
 311        values
 312        """
 313        self.x_data: pd.DataFrame = x_data.loc[join_index, :]
 314        """
 315        The data to be calibrated.
 316        """
 317        self.target: str = target
 318        """
 319        The name of the column in both `x_data` and `y_data` that
 320        will be used as the x and y variables in the calibration.
 321        """
 322        self.scaler_list: dict[str, Any] = {
 323            "None": None,
 324            "Standard Scale": pre.StandardScaler(),
 325            "MinMax Scale": pre.MinMaxScaler(),
 326            "Yeo-Johnson Transform": pre.PowerTransformer(
 327                method="yeo-johnson"
 328            ),
 329            "Box-Cox Transform": pre.PowerTransformer(method="box-cox"),
 330            "Quantile Transform (Uniform)": pre.QuantileTransformer(
 331                output_distribution="uniform"
 332            ),
 333            "Quantile Transform (Gaussian)": pre.QuantileTransformer(
 334                output_distribution="normal"
 335            ),
 336        }
 337        """
 338        Keys for scaling algorithms available in the pipelines
 339        """
 340        self.scaler: list[str] = list()
 341        """
 342        The scaling algorithm(s) to preprocess the data with
 343        """
 344        self.y_data = cont_strat_folds(
 345            y_data.loc[join_index, :],
 346            target,
 347            folds,
 348            strat_groups,
 349            validation_size,
 350            seed,
 351        )
 352        """
 353        The data that `x_data` will be calibrated against. A '*Fold*'
 354        column is added using the `const_strat_folds` function which splits
 355        the data into k stratified folds (where k is the value of
 356        `folds`). It splits the continuous measurements into n bins (where n
 357        is the value of `strat_groups`) and distributes each bin equally
 358        across all folds. This significantly reduces the chances of one fold
 359        containing a skewed distribution relative to the whole dataset.
 360        """
 361        if isinstance(scaler, str):
 362            if scaler == "All":
 363                if bool(self.x_data.le(0).any(axis=None)) or bool(
 364                    self.y_data.drop("Fold", axis=1).le(0).any(axis=None)
 365                ):
 366                    self.scaler_list.pop("Box-Cox Transform")
 367                    warnings.warn(
 368                        "WARN: "
 369                        "Box-Cox is not compatible with provided measurements"
 370                    )
 371                self.scaler.extend(self.scaler_list.keys())
 372            elif scaler in self.scaler_list.keys():
 373                self.scaler.append(scaler)
 374            else:
 375                self.scaler.append("None")
 376                warnings.warn(f"Scaling algorithm {scaler} not recognised")
 377        elif isinstance(scaler, (tuple, list)):
 378            for sc in scaler:
 379                if sc == "Box-Cox Transform" and not any(
 380                    (
 381                        bool(self.x_data.lt(0).any(axis=None)),
 382                        bool(self.y_data.lt(0).any(axis=None)),
 383                    )
 384                ):
 385                    warnings.warn(
 386                        "Box-Cox is not compatible with provided measurements"
 387                    )
 388                    continue
 389                if sc in self.scaler_list.keys():
 390                    self.scaler.append(sc)
 391                else:
 392                    warnings.warn(f"Scaling algorithm {sc} not recognised")
 393        else:
 394            raise ValueError(
 395                "scaler parameter should be string, list or tuple"
 396            )
 397        if not self.scaler:
 398            warnings.warn(
 399                "No valid scaling algorithms provided, defaulting to None"
 400            )
 401            self.scaler.append("None")
 402
 403        self.models: dict[
 404            str,  # Technique name
 405            dict[
 406                str,  # Scaling technique
 407                dict[str, dict[int, Pipeline]],  # Variable combo  # Fold
 408            ],
 409        ] = dict()
 410        """
 411        The calibrated models. They are stored in a nested structure as
 412        follows:
 413        1. Primary Key, name of the technique (e.g Lasso Regression).
 414        2. Scaling technique (e.g Yeo-Johnson Transform).
 415        3. Combination of variables used or `target` if calibration is
 416        univariate (e.g "`target` + a + b).
 417        4. Fold, which fold was used excluded from the calibration. If data
 418        if 5-fold cross validated, a key of 4 indicates the data was trained on
 419        folds 0-3.
 420
 421        ```mermaid
 422            stateDiagram-v2
 423              models --> Technique
 424              state Technique {
 425                [*] --> Scaling
 426                [*]: The calibration technique used
 427                [*]: (e.g "Lasso Regression")
 428                state Scaling {
 429                  [*] --> Variables
 430                  [*]: The scaling technique used
 431                  [*]: (e.g "Yeo-Johnson Transform")
 432                  state Variables {
 433                    [*] : The combination of variables used
 434                    [*] : (e.g "x + a + b")
 435                    [*] --> Fold
 436                    state Fold {
 437                     [*] : Which fold was excluded from training data
 438                     [*] : (e.g 4 indicates folds 0-3 were used to train)
 439                    }
 440                  }
 441                }
 442              }
 443        ```
 444
 445        """
 446        self.folds: int = folds
 447        """
 448        The number of folds used in k-fold cross validation
 449        """
 450        self.rs_iter: int = random_search_iterations
 451        """
 452        Number of iterations to use in random search
 453        """
 454        self.verbosity: int = verbosity
 455        """
 456        Verbosity of output when using random search
 457        """
 458        self.n_jobs: int = n_jobs
 459        """
 460        Number of processor cores to use
 461        """
 462        self.pkl = pickle_path
 463        """
 464        Path to save pickle files to, or None if pipelines are stored in memory
 465        """
 466        self.all_sec_vals = all_sec_vals
 467        """
 468        Whether to test all combinations of secondary variables or just
 469        all/none
 470        """
 471
 472    def _sklearn_regression_meta(
 473        self,
 474        reg: Union[
 475            skl.base.RegressorMixin,
 476            RandomizedSearchCV,
 477            GAM,
 478            Literal["t", "gaussian"],
 479        ],
 480        name: str,
 481        min_coeffs: int = 1,
 482        max_coeffs: int = (sys.maxsize * 2) + 1,
 483        random_search: bool = False,
 484    ):
 485        """
 486        Metaclass, formats data and uses sklearn classifier to
 487        fit x to y
 488
 489        Parameters
 490        ----------
 491        reg : sklearn.base.RegressorMixin or str
 492            Classifier to use, or distribution family to use for bayesian.
 493        name : str
 494            Name of classification technique to save pipeline to.
 495        min_coeffs : int, default=1
 496            Minimum number of coefficients for technique.
 497        max_coeffs : int, default=(sys.maxsize * 2) + 1
 498            Maximum number of coefficients for technique.
 499        random_search : bool
 500            Whether RandomizedSearch is used or not
 501
 502        Raises
 503        ------
 504        NotImplementedError
 505            PyMC currently doesn't work, TODO
 506        """
 507        x_secondary_cols = self.x_data.drop(self.target, axis=1).columns
 508        # All columns in x_data that aren't the target variable
 509        if len(x_secondary_cols) > 0:
 510            if self.all_sec_vals:
 511                products = [[np.nan, col] for col in x_secondary_cols]
 512                secondary_vals = pd.MultiIndex.from_product(products)
 513            else:
 514                secondary_vals = [None, list(x_secondary_cols)]
 515        else:
 516            secondary_vals = [None]
 517        # Get all possible combinations of secondary variables in a pandas
 518        # MultiIndex
 519        if self.models.get(name) is None:
 520            self.models[name] = dict()
 521            # If the classification technique hasn't been used yet,
 522            # add its key to the models dictionary
 523        for scaler in self.scaler:
 524            if self.models[name].get(scaler) is None:
 525                self.models[name][scaler] = dict()
 526                # If the scaling technique hasn't been used with the
 527                # classification
 528                # technique yet, add its key to the nested dictionary
 529            for sec_vals in secondary_vals:
 530                # Loop over all combinations of secondary values
 531                if sec_vals is not None:
 532                    vals = [self.target] + [v for v in sec_vals if v == v]
 533                else:
 534                    vals = [self.target]
 535                vals_str = " + ".join(vals)
 536                if len(vals) < min_coeffs or len(vals) > max_coeffs:
 537                    # Skip if number of coeffs doesn't lie within acceptable
 538                    # range
 539                    # for technique. For example, isotonic regression
 540                    # only works with one variable
 541                    continue
 542                self.models[name][scaler][vals_str] = dict()
 543                #                if random_search:
 544                #                    pipeline = Pipeline([
 545                #                        ("Selector", ColumnTransformer([
 546                #                       ("selector", "passthrough", vals)
 547                #                            ], remainder="drop")
 548                #                         ),
 549                #                        ("Scaler", self.scaler_list[scaler]),
 550                #                        ("Regression", reg)
 551                #                        ])
 552                #                    pipeline.fit(
 553                #                        self.x_data,
 554                #                        self.y_data.loc[:, self.target]
 555                #                            )
 556                #   self.models[name][scaler][vals_str][0] = dc(pipeline)
 557                #                    continue
 558                #
 559                for fold in self.y_data.loc[:, "Fold"].unique():
 560                    if fold == "Validation":
 561                        continue
 562                    y_data = self.y_data[
 563                        ~self.y_data.loc[:, "Fold"].isin([fold, "Validation"])
 564                    ]
 565                    if reg in ["t", "gaussian"]:
 566                        # If using PyMC bayesian model,
 567                        # then store result in pipeline
 568                        # Currently doesn't work as PyMC models
 569                        # can't be pickled, so don't function with deepcopy.
 570                        # Needs looking into
 571                        raise NotImplementedError(
 572                            "PyMC functions currently don't work with deepcopy"
 573                        )
 574                    #                    sc = scalers[scaler]
 575                    #                    if sc is not None:
 576                    #                        x_data = sc.fit_transform(
 577                    #                   self.x_data.loc[y_data.index, :]
 578                    #                                )
 579                    #                    else:
 580                    #           x_data = self.x_data.loc[y_data.index, :]
 581                    #               x_data['y'] = y_data.loc[:, self.target]
 582                    #                    model = bmb.Model(
 583                    #                            f"y ~ {vals_str}",
 584                    #                            x_data,
 585                    #                            family=reg
 586                    #                            )
 587                    #                    _ = model.fit(
 588                    #                        progressbar=False,
 589                    #                        **kwargs
 590                    #                        )
 591                    #                    pipeline = Pipeline([
 592                    #                        ("Scaler", scaler),
 593                    #                        ("Regression", model)
 594                    #                        ])
 595                    else:
 596                        # If using scikit-learn API compatible classifier,
 597                        # Build pipeline and fit to
 598                        pipeline = Pipeline(
 599                            [
 600                                (
 601                                    "Selector",
 602                                    ColumnTransformer(
 603                                        [("selector", "passthrough", vals)],
 604                                        remainder="drop",
 605                                    ),
 606                                ),
 607                                ("Scaler", self.scaler_list[scaler]),
 608                                ("Regression", reg),
 609                            ]
 610                        )
 611                        pipeline.fit(
 612                            self.x_data.loc[y_data.index, :],
 613                            y_data.loc[:, self.target],
 614                        )
 615                    if isinstance(self.pkl, Path):
 616                        pkl_path = self.pkl / name / scaler / vals_str
 617                        pkl_path.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
 618                        pkl_file = pkl_path / f"{fold}.pkl"
 619                        with pkl_file.open("wb") as pkl:
 620                            pickle.dump(pipeline, pkl)
 621                        self.models[name][scaler][vals_str][fold] = pkl_file
 622                    else:
 623                        self.models[name][scaler][vals_str][fold] = dc(
 624                            pipeline
 625                        )
 626
 627    def pymc_bayesian(
 628        self,
 629        family: Literal[
 630            "Gaussian",
 631            "Student T",
 632        ] = "Gaussian",
 633        name: str = " PyMC Bayesian",
 634        **kwargs,
 635    ):
 636        """
 637        Performs bayesian linear regression (either uni or multivariate)
 638        fitting x on y.
 639
 640        Performs bayesian linear regression, both univariate and multivariate,
 641        on X against y. More details can be found at:
 642        https://pymc.io/projects/examples/en/latest/generalized_linear_models/
 643        GLM-robust.html
 644
 645        Parameters
 646        ----------
 647        family : {'Gaussian', 'Student T'}, default='Gaussian'
 648            Statistical distribution to fit measurements to. Options are:
 649                - Gaussian
 650                - Student T
 651        """
 652        # Define model families
 653        model_families: dict[str, Literal["t", "gaussian"]] = {
 654            "Gaussian": "gaussian",
 655            "Student T": "t",
 656        }
 657        self._sklearn_regression_meta(
 658            model_families[family], f"{name} ({model_families})", **kwargs
 659        )
 660
 661    def linreg(
 662        self,
 663        name: str = "Linear Regression",
 664        random_search: bool = False,
 665        parameters: dict[
 666            str, Union[scipy.stats.rv_continuous, List[Union[int, str, float]]]
 667        ] = {},
 668        **kwargs,
 669    ):
 670        """
 671        Fit x on y via linear regression
 672
 673        Parameters
 674        ----------
 675        name : str, default="Linear Regression"
 676            Name of classification technique.
 677        random_search : bool, default=False
 678            Whether to perform RandomizedSearch to optimise parameters
 679        parameters : dict[
 680                str,
 681                Union[
 682                    scipy.stats.rv_continuous,
 683                    List[Union[int, str, float]]
 684                ]
 685            ], default=Preset distributions
 686            The parameters used in RandomizedSearchCV
 687        """
 688        if random_search:
 689            classifier = RandomizedSearchCV(
 690                lm.LinearRegression(**kwargs),
 691                parameters,
 692                n_iter=self.rs_iter,
 693                verbose=self.verbosity,
 694                n_jobs=self.n_jobs,
 695                cv=self.folds,
 696            )
 697        else:
 698            classifier = lm.LinearRegression(**kwargs)
 699        self._sklearn_regression_meta(
 700            classifier,
 701            f'{name}{" (Random Search)" if random_search else ""}',
 702            random_search=random_search,
 703        )
 704

1059    def bayesian_ridge(
1060        self,
1061        name: str = "Bayesian Ridge Regression",
1062        random_search: bool = False,
1063        parameters: dict[
1064            str, Union[scipy.stats.rv_continuous, List[Union[int, str, float]]]
1065        ] = {
1066            "tol": uniform(loc=0, scale=1),
1067            "alpha_1": uniform(loc=0, scale=1),
1068            "alpha_2": uniform(loc=0, scale=1),
1069            "lambda_1": uniform(loc=0, scale=1),
1070            "lambda_2": uniform(loc=0, scale=1),
1071        },
1072        **kwargs,
1073    ):
1074        """
1075        Fit x on y via bayesian ridge regression
1076
1077        Parameters
1078        ----------
1079        name : str, default="Bayesian Ridge Regression"
1080            Name of classification technique.

2366
2367    def return_measurements(self) -> dict[str, pd.DataFrame]:
2368        """
2369        Returns the measurements used, with missing values and
2370        non-overlapping measurements excluded
2371
2372        Returns
2373        -------
2374        dict[str, pd.DataFrame]
2375            Dictionary with 2 keys:
2376
2377            |Key|Value|
2378            |---|---|
2379            |x|`x_data`|
2380            |y|`y_data`|
2381
2382        """
2383        return {"x": self.x_data, "y": self.y_data}
2384
2385    def return_models(
2386        self,
2387    ) -> dict[
2388        str,  # Technique
2389        dict[
2390            str,  # Scaling method
2391            dict[str, dict[int, Pipeline]],  # Variables used  # Fold
2392        ],
2393    ]:
2394        """
2395        Returns the models stored in the object
2396
2397        Returns
2398        -------
2399        dict[str, str, str, int, Pipeline]
2400            The calibrated models. They are stored in a nested structure as
2401            follows:
2402            1. Primary Key, name of the technique (e.g Lasso Regression).
2403            2. Scaling technique (e.g Yeo-Johnson Transform).
2404            3. Combination of variables used or `target` if calibration is
2405            univariate (e.g "`target` + a + b).
2406            4. Fold, which fold was used excluded from the calibration. If data
2407            folds 0-3.
2408            if 5-fold cross validated, a key of 4 indicates the data was
2409            trained on
2410        """
2411        return self.models
2412
2413    def clear_models(self):
2414        """ """
2415        del self.models
2416        self.models = dict()

Calibrate x against y using a range of different methods provided by scikit-learn1, xgboost2 and PyMC (via Bambi)3.

Examples
>>> from calidhayte.calibrate import Calibrate
>>> import pandas as pd
>>>
>>> x = pd.read_csv('independent.csv')
>>> x
|   | a | b |
| 0 |2.3|3.2|
| 1 |3.4|3.1|
|...|...|...|
|100|3.7|2.1|
>>>
>>> y = pd.read_csv('dependent.csv')
>>> y
|   | a |
| 0 |7.8|
| 1 |9.9|
|...|...|
|100|9.5|
>>>
>>> calibration = Calibrate(
    x_data=x,
    y_data=y,
    target='a',
    folds=5,
    strat_groups=5,
    scaler = [
        'Standard Scale',
        'MinMax Scale'
        ],
    seed=62
)
>>> calibration.linreg()
>>> calibration.lars()
>>> calibration.omp()
>>> calibration.ransac()
>>> calibration.random_forest()
>>>
>>> models = calibration.return_models()
>>> list(models.keys())
[
    'Linear Regression',
    'Least Angle Regression',
    'Orthogonal Matching Pursuit',
    'RANSAC',
    'Random Forest'
]
>>> list(models['Linear Regression'].keys())
['Standard Scale', 'MinMax Scale']
>>> list(models['Linear Regression']['Standard Scale'].keys())
['a', 'a + b']
>>> list(models['Linear Regression']['Standard Scale']['a'].keys())
[0, 1, 2, 3, 4]
>>> type(models['Linear Regression']['Standard Scale']['a'][0])
<class sklearn.pipeline.Pipeline>
>>> pipeline = models['Linear Regression']['Standard Scale']['a'][0]
>>> x_new = pd.read_csv('independent_new.csv')
>>> x_new
|   | a | b |
| 0 |3.5|2.7|
| 1 |4.0|1.1|
|...|...|...|
|100|2.3|2.1|
>>> pipeline.transform(x_new)
|   | a |
| 0 |9.7|
| 1 |9.1|
|...|...|
|100|6.7|

  1. https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/classes.html ↩

  2. https://xgboost.readthedocs.io/en/stable/python/python_api.html ↩

  3. https://bambinos.github.io/bambi/api/ ↩

Calibrate( x_data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, y_data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, target: str, all_sec_vals: bool = False, folds: int = 5, strat_groups: int = 10, scaler: Union[collections.abc.Iterable[Literal['None', 'Standard Scale', 'MinMax Scale', 'Yeo-Johnson Transform', 'Box-Cox Transform', 'Quantile Transform (Uniform)', 'Quantile Transform (Gaussian)']], Literal['All', 'None', 'Standard Scale', 'MinMax Scale', 'Yeo-Johnson Transform', 'Box-Cox Transform', 'Quantile Transform (Uniform)', 'Quantile Transform (Gaussian)']] = 'None', random_search_iterations: int = 25, validation_size: float = 0.1, verbosity: int = 0, n_jobs: int = -1, pickle_path: Optional[pathlib.Path] = None, seed: int = 62) 
210    def __init__(
211        self,
212        x_data: pd.DataFrame,
213        y_data: pd.DataFrame,
214        target: str,
215        all_sec_vals: bool = False,
216        folds: int = 5,
217        strat_groups: int = 10,
218        scaler: Union[
219            Iterable[
220                Literal[
221                    "None",
222                    "Standard Scale",
223                    "MinMax Scale",
224                    "Yeo-Johnson Transform",
225                    "Box-Cox Transform",
226                    "Quantile Transform (Uniform)",
227                    "Quantile Transform (Gaussian)",
228                ]
229            ],
230            Literal[
231                "All",
232                "None",
233                "Standard Scale",
234                "MinMax Scale",
235                "Yeo-Johnson Transform",
236                "Box-Cox Transform",
237                "Quantile Transform (Uniform)",
238                "Quantile Transform (Gaussian)",
239            ],
240        ] = "None",
241        random_search_iterations: int = 25,
242        validation_size: float = 0.1,
243        verbosity: int = 0,
244        n_jobs: int = -1,
245        pickle_path: Optional[Path] = None,
246        seed: int = 62,
247    ):
248        """Initialises class
249
250        Used to compare one set of measurements against another.
251        It can perform both univariate and multivariate regression, though
252        some techniques can only do one or the other. Multivariate regression
253        can only be performed when secondary variables are provided.
254
255        Parameters
256        ----------
257        x_data : pd.DataFrame
258            Data to be calibrated.
259        y_data : pd.DataFrame
260            'True' data to calibrate against.
261        target : str
262            Column name of the primary feature to use in calibration, must be
263            the name of a column in both `x_data` and `y_data`.
264        all_sec_vals : bool, default=False
265            Iterate over all secondary variable combinations or just all/none
266        folds : int, default=5
267            Number of folds to split the data into, using stratified k-fold.
268        strat_groups : int, default=10
269            Number of groups to stratify against, the data will be split into
270            n equally sized bins where n is the value of `strat_groups`.
271        scaler : iterable of {<br>\
272            'None',<br>\
273            'Standard Scale',<br>\
274            'MinMax Scale',<br>\
275            'Yeo-Johnson Transform',<br>\
276            'Box-Cox Transform',<br>\
277            'Quantile Transform (Uniform)',<br>\
278            'Quantile Transform (Gaussian)',<br>\
279            } or {<br>\
280            'All',<br>\
281            'None',<br>\
282            'Standard Scale',<br>\
283            'MinMax Scale',<br>\
284            'Yeo-Johnson Transform',<br>\
285            'Box-Cox Transform',<br>\
286            'Quantile Transform (Uniform)',<br>\
287            'Quantile Transform (Gaussian)',<br>\
288            }, default='None'
289            The scaling/transform method (or list of methods) to apply to the
290            data
291        seed : int, default=62
292            Random state to use when shuffling and splitting the data into n
293            folds. Ensures repeatability.
294
295        Raises
296        ------
297        ValueError
298            Raised if the target variables (e.g. 'NO2') is not a column name in
299            both dataframes.
300            Raised if `scaler` is not str, tuple or list
301        """
302        if target not in x_data.columns or target not in y_data.columns:
303            raise ValueError(f"{target} does not exist in both columns.")
304        join_index = (
305            x_data.join(y_data, how="inner", lsuffix="x", rsuffix="y")
306            .dropna()
307            .index
308        )
309        """
310        The common indices between `x_data` and `y_data`, excluding missing
311        values
312        """
313        self.x_data: pd.DataFrame = x_data.loc[join_index, :]
314        """
315        The data to be calibrated.
316        """
317        self.target: str = target
318        """
319        The name of the column in both `x_data` and `y_data` that
320        will be used as the x and y variables in the calibration.
321        """
322        self.scaler_list: dict[str, Any] = {
323            "None": None,
324            "Standard Scale": pre.StandardScaler(),
325            "MinMax Scale": pre.MinMaxScaler(),
326            "Yeo-Johnson Transform": pre.PowerTransformer(
327                method="yeo-johnson"
328            ),
329            "Box-Cox Transform": pre.PowerTransformer(method="box-cox"),
330            "Quantile Transform (Uniform)": pre.QuantileTransformer(
331                output_distribution="uniform"
332            ),
333            "Quantile Transform (Gaussian)": pre.QuantileTransformer(
334                output_distribution="normal"
335            ),
336        }
337        """
338        Keys for scaling algorithms available in the pipelines
339        """
340        self.scaler: list[str] = list()
341        """
342        The scaling algorithm(s) to preprocess the data with
343        """
344        self.y_data = cont_strat_folds(
345            y_data.loc[join_index, :],
346            target,
347            folds,
348            strat_groups,
349            validation_size,
350            seed,
351        )
352        """
353        The data that `x_data` will be calibrated against. A '*Fold*'
354        column is added using the `const_strat_folds` function which splits
355        the data into k stratified folds (where k is the value of
356        `folds`). It splits the continuous measurements into n bins (where n
357        is the value of `strat_groups`) and distributes each bin equally
358        across all folds. This significantly reduces the chances of one fold
359        containing a skewed distribution relative to the whole dataset.
360        """
361        if isinstance(scaler, str):
362            if scaler == "All":
363                if bool(self.x_data.le(0).any(axis=None)) or bool(
364                    self.y_data.drop("Fold", axis=1).le(0).any(axis=None)
365                ):
366                    self.scaler_list.pop("Box-Cox Transform")
367                    warnings.warn(
368                        "WARN: "
369                        "Box-Cox is not compatible with provided measurements"
370                    )
371                self.scaler.extend(self.scaler_list.keys())
372            elif scaler in self.scaler_list.keys():
373                self.scaler.append(scaler)
374            else:
375                self.scaler.append("None")
376                warnings.warn(f"Scaling algorithm {scaler} not recognised")
377        elif isinstance(scaler, (tuple, list)):
378            for sc in scaler:
379                if sc == "Box-Cox Transform" and not any(
380                    (
381                        bool(self.x_data.lt(0).any(axis=None)),
382                        bool(self.y_data.lt(0).any(axis=None)),
383                    )
384                ):
385                    warnings.warn(
386                        "Box-Cox is not compatible with provided measurements"
387                    )
388                    continue
389                if sc in self.scaler_list.keys():
390                    self.scaler.append(sc)
391                else:
392                    warnings.warn(f"Scaling algorithm {sc} not recognised")
393        else:
394            raise ValueError(
395                "scaler parameter should be string, list or tuple"
396            )
397        if not self.scaler:
398            warnings.warn(
399                "No valid scaling algorithms provided, defaulting to None"
400            )
401            self.scaler.append("None")
402
403        self.models: dict[
404            str,  # Technique name
405            dict[
406                str,  # Scaling technique
407                dict[str, dict[int, Pipeline]],  # Variable combo  # Fold
408            ],
409        ] = dict()
410        """
411        The calibrated models. They are stored in a nested structure as
412        follows:
413        1. Primary Key, name of the technique (e.g Lasso Regression).
414        2. Scaling technique (e.g Yeo-Johnson Transform).
415        3. Combination of variables used or `target` if calibration is
416        univariate (e.g "`target` + a + b).
417        4. Fold, which fold was used excluded from the calibration. If data
418        if 5-fold cross validated, a key of 4 indicates the data was trained on
419        folds 0-3.
420
421        ```mermaid
422            stateDiagram-v2
423              models --> Technique
424              state Technique {
425                [*] --> Scaling
426                [*]: The calibration technique used
427                [*]: (e.g "Lasso Regression")
428                state Scaling {
429                  [*] --> Variables
430                  [*]: The scaling technique used
431                  [*]: (e.g "Yeo-Johnson Transform")
432                  state Variables {
433                    [*] : The combination of variables used
434                    [*] : (e.g "x + a + b")
435                    [*] --> Fold
436                    state Fold {
437                     [*] : Which fold was excluded from training data
438                     [*] : (e.g 4 indicates folds 0-3 were used to train)
439                    }
440                  }
441                }
442              }
443        ```
444
445        """
446        self.folds: int = folds
447        """
448        The number of folds used in k-fold cross validation
449        """
450        self.rs_iter: int = random_search_iterations
451        """
452        Number of iterations to use in random search
453        """
454        self.verbosity: int = verbosity
455        """
456        Verbosity of output when using random search
457        """
458        self.n_jobs: int = n_jobs
459        """
460        Number of processor cores to use
461        """
462        self.pkl = pickle_path
463        """
464        Path to save pickle files to, or None if pipelines are stored in memory
465        """
466        self.all_sec_vals = all_sec_vals
467        """
468        Whether to test all combinations of secondary variables or just
469        all/none
470        """

Initialises class

Used to compare one set of measurements against another. It can perform both univariate and multivariate regression, though some techniques can only do one or the other. Multivariate regression can only be performed when secondary variables are provided.

Parameters
  • x_data (pd.DataFrame): Data to be calibrated.
  • y_data (pd.DataFrame): 'True' data to calibrate against.
  • target (str): Column name of the primary feature to use in calibration, must be the name of a column in both x_data and y_data.
  • all_sec_vals (bool, default=False): Iterate over all secondary variable combinations or just all/none
  • folds (int, default=5): Number of folds to split the data into, using stratified k-fold.
  • strat_groups (int, default=10): Number of groups to stratify against, the data will be split into n equally sized bins where n is the value of strat_groups.
  • scaler (iterable of {
    'None',
    'Standard Scale',
    'MinMax Scale',
    'Yeo-Johnson Transform',
    'Box-Cox Transform',
    'Quantile Transform (Uniform)',
    'Quantile Transform (Gaussian)',
    } or {
    'All',
    'None',
    'Standard Scale',
    'MinMax Scale',
    'Yeo-Johnson Transform',
    'Box-Cox Transform',
    'Quantile Transform (Uniform)',
    'Quantile Transform (Gaussian)',
    }, default='None'): The scaling/transform method (or list of methods) to apply to the data
  • seed (int, default=62): Random state to use when shuffling and splitting the data into n folds. Ensures repeatability.
Raises
  • ValueError: Raised if the target variables (e.g. 'NO2') is not a column name in both dataframes. Raised if scaler is not str, tuple or list
x_data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame

The data to be calibrated.

target: str

The name of the column in both x_data and y_data that will be used as the x and y variables in the calibration.

scaler_list: dict[str, typing.Any]

Keys for scaling algorithms available in the pipelines

scaler: list[str]

The scaling algorithm(s) to preprocess the data with

y_data

The data that x_data will be calibrated against. A 'Fold' column is added using the const_strat_folds function which splits the data into k stratified folds (where k is the value of folds). It splits the continuous measurements into n bins (where n is the value of strat_groups) and distributes each bin equally across all folds. This significantly reduces the chances of one fold containing a skewed distribution relative to the whole dataset.

models: dict[str, dict[str, dict[str, dict[int, sklearn.pipeline.Pipeline]]]]

The calibrated models. They are stored in a nested structure as follows:

  1. Primary Key, name of the technique (e.g Lasso Regression).
  2. Scaling technique (e.g Yeo-Johnson Transform).
  3. Combination of variables used or target if calibration is univariate (e.g "target + a + b).
  4. Fold, which fold was used excluded from the calibration. If data if 5-fold cross validated, a key of 4 indicates the data was trained on folds 0-3.
    stateDiagram-v2
      models --> Technique
      state Technique {
        [*] --> Scaling
        [*]: The calibration technique used
        [*]: (e.g "Lasso Regression")
        state Scaling {
          [*] --> Variables
          [*]: The scaling technique used
          [*]: (e.g "Yeo-Johnson Transform")
          state Variables {
            [*] : The combination of variables used
            [*] : (e.g "x + a + b")
            [*] --> Fold
            state Fold {
             [*] : Which fold was excluded from training data
             [*] : (e.g 4 indicates folds 0-3 were used to train)
            }
          }
        }
      }
folds: int

The number of folds used in k-fold cross validation

rs_iter: int

Number of iterations to use in random search

verbosity: int

Verbosity of output when using random search

n_jobs: int

Number of processor cores to use

pkl

Path to save pickle files to, or None if pipelines are stored in memory

all_sec_vals

Whether to test all combinations of secondary variables or just all/none

def pymc_bayesian( self, family: Literal['Gaussian', 'Student T'] = 'Gaussian', name: str = ' PyMC Bayesian', **kwargs): 
627    def pymc_bayesian(
628        self,
629        family: Literal[
630            "Gaussian",
631            "Student T",
632        ] = "Gaussian",
633        name: str = " PyMC Bayesian",
634        **kwargs,
635    ):
636        """
637        Performs bayesian linear regression (either uni or multivariate)
638        fitting x on y.
639
640        Performs bayesian linear regression, both univariate and multivariate,
641        on X against y. More details can be found at:
642        https://pymc.io/projects/examples/en/latest/generalized_linear_models/
643        GLM-robust.html
644
645        Parameters
646        ----------
647        family : {'Gaussian', 'Student T'}, default='Gaussian'
648            Statistical distribution to fit measurements to. Options are:
649                - Gaussian
650                - Student T
651        """
652        # Define model families
653        model_families: dict[str, Literal["t", "gaussian"]] = {
654            "Gaussian": "gaussian",
655            "Student T": "t",
656        }
657        self._sklearn_regression_meta(
658            model_families[family], f"{name} ({model_families})", **kwargs
659        )

def linreg( self, name: str = 'Linear Regression', random_search: bool = False, parameters: dict[str, typing.Union[scipy.stats._distn_infrastructure.rv_continuous, typing.List[typing.Union[int, str, float]]]] = {}, **kwargs): 
661    def linreg(
662        self,
663        name: str = "Linear Regression",
664        random_search: bool = False,
665        parameters: dict[
666            str, Union[scipy.stats.rv_continuous, List[Union[int, str, float]]]
667        ] = {},
668        **kwargs,
669    ):
670        """
671        Fit x on y via linear regression
672
673        Parameters
674        ----------
675        name : str, default="Linear Regression"
676            Name of classification technique.
677        random_search : bool, default=False
678            Whether to perform RandomizedSearch to optimise parameters
679        parameters : dict[
680                str,
681                Union[
682                    scipy.stats.rv_continuous,
683                    List[Union[int, str, float]]
684                ]
685            ], default=Preset distributions
686            The parameters used in RandomizedSearchCV
687        """
688        if random_search:
689            classifier = RandomizedSearchCV(
690                lm.LinearRegression(**kwargs),
691                parameters,
692                n_iter=self.rs_iter,
693                verbose=self.verbosity,
694                n_jobs=self.n_jobs,
695                cv=self.folds,
696            )
697        else:
698            classifier = lm.LinearRegression(**kwargs)
699        self._sklearn_regression_meta(
700            classifier,
701            f'{name}{" (Random Search)" if random_search else ""}',
702            random_search=random_search,
703        )

    3. Combination of variables used or target if calibration is univariate (e.g "target + a + b).
